thread.title: VMware to Form Cloud Business With EMC
thread.title_full: VMware to Form Cloud Business With EMC

author: morningstar.com
title: VMware to Form Cloud Business With EMC
text:
VMware Inc. on Tuesday unveiled plans to form a new cloud-services business with its majority-owner EMC Corp., while reporting a 10% increase in revenue for its third quarter.
EMC earlier this month agreed to sell itself to Dell Inc. and private-equity firm Silver Lake for $67 billion in what would be the largest technology-industry takeover ever.
VMware, which provides virtualization software that allows servers and other technology equipment to run more efficiently, is expected remain a publicly traded company, and Dell will become its largest shareholder.
Investors in VMware have been spooked by the deal, which analysts say could affect VMware's ability to retain top talent in the tight Silicon Valley labor market and could dilute demand for its shares.
Shares of VMware, down 13% this month, ticked down 0.3% in after-hours trading.
VMware said it plans to form a new cloud-services business that it will jointly own with EMC by early 2016. The new business will operate under the Virtustream brand and is expected to have hundreds of millions of dollars in recurring revenue next year.
Results from the business will be consolidated into VMware's financial statements starting in the first quarter of 2016.
Meanwhile, VMware said revenue grew 10% to $1.67 billion in the third quarter, in line with the guidance the company gave when it reported preliminary third-quarter results earlier this month.
VMware's profit grew to $256 million, or 60 cents a share, from $194 million, or 45 cents a year earlier.
Excluding certain items, per-share earnings rose to $1.02 a share from 87 cents a share a year earlier.
Analysts had forecast earnings of $1 a share on revenue of $1.66 billion, according to Thomson Reuters.
Dell is expected to open $1 billion in new opportunities for VMware to sell its virtualization software, which makes computers more efficient by allowing them to run more than one operating system simultaneously.
However, VMware can't appear to favor Dell in ways that would hurt its customers that buy servers from Hewlett-Packard Inc. or Lenovo Group Ltd.--Dell's arch rivalsâ€”or that could hurt it in the virtualization market, where VMware competes with Microsoft Corp., Red Hat Inc. and a variety of alternatives.
